Sense.DEF: a short piece taken from a book, poem, piece of music etc
Sense.TRAN: 〔书籍﹑诗歌﹑音乐等的〕摘录﹐节录

GramExa.EXAMPLE: An excerpt of the speech appeared in the Sunday paper.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 演讲的节录刊登在周日报纸上了。

Sense.DEF: a larger amount of something than is allowed or needed
Sense.EXAMPLE: After you apply the oil, wait 20 minutes before wiping off any excess.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 涂上油以后﹐等20分钟再擦掉多余部分。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: It was an excess of enthusiasm that caused the problem.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 是过度热情引起了这一问题。

Sense.DEF: more than a particular amount
Sense.EXAMPLE: The car reached speeds in excess of 100 miles per hour.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这辆汽车的时速超过了100英里。

Sense.DEF: to do something too much or too often, so that it may harm you
Sense.EXAMPLE: Drinking is OK as long as you don’t do it to excess.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 饮酒可以﹐只要不过量。

Sense.DEF: harmful actions that are socially or morally unacceptable

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The government was unable to curb the excesses of the secret police.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 政府无法约束秘密警察的过分行为。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: the worst excesses of journalism
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 新闻工作中那些最糟糕的越轨行为

Sense.DEF: behaviour which is not acceptable because it is too extreme
Sense.EXAMPLE: a long sermon against the dangers of excess
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 告诫极端行为会造成危害的长篇大论

Sense.DEF: additional and not needed because there is already enough of something
Sense.EXAMPLE: Cut any excess fat from the meat.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 将肉中多余的肥肉切掉。

Sense.DEF: bags or cases that weigh more than the legal limit that you can take on a plane
much more than is reasonable or necessary
Sense.EXAMPLE: his excessive drinking
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他的酗酒
Sense.EXAMPLE: $15 for two beers seems a little excessive.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 两杯啤酒要15美元﹐似乎有点过分。

Sense.DEF: the act of giving someone something and receiving something else from them

GramExa.EXAMPLE: an exchange of political prisoners
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 互换政治犯

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I’ve offered to paint the kitchen in exchange for a week’s accommodation.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我提出愿意粉刷厨房﹐条件是让我免费住一周。

Sense.EXAMPLE: Four of my cassettes for your Madonna CD is a fair exchange.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我用四盒磁带换你的麦当娜激光唱片很公平。

Sense.DEF: a short conversation, usually between two people who are angry with each other
Sense.TRAN: 短时间的交谈〔通常指两人相互生气时〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: a quiet exchange between the judge and the clerk
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 法官和书记员轻声交换意见
Sense.EXAMPLE: The DJ was fired after a heated exchange a very angry conversation on air with a call-in listener.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那个音乐节目主持人在节目中和一名打电话来的收听者大吵了一顿﹐之后就被解雇了。

Sense.DEF: when people discuss or share ideas, information etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: The organization is dedicated to the free exchange of information.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 该机构致力于信息的自由交流。

Sense.DEF: the act of giving something you have bought back to the store where you bought it, for example because it does not work, fit etc, and taking something else instead
Sense.EXAMPLE: The store’s policy is not to allow returns or exchanges.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 该商店规定货品概不退换。

Sense.DEF: a process in which you change money from one currency to another
Sense.EXAMPLE: Most capital cities have extensive exchange facilities.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 大部分首府城市都有大量外汇兑换处。

Sense.DEF: an arrangement in which a student, teacher etc visits another school or university to work or study

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I’m here for one term, on an exchange with Dr. Fisher.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我在这里待一个学期﹐与费希尔博士作互访。

Sense.DEF: an arrangement in which you stay in someone’s home, do someone’s job etc for a short time while that person stays in your home, does your job etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: Kate’s in New York on an employee exchange so she can get some more training.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 凯特在纽约参加雇员交换﹐这样她可以受到更多的培训。

Sense.DEF: an event during a war or fight when two people, armies etc shoot or fire missiles at each other
a large building in a town that was used in the past for buying and selling corn, wool etc
Sense.TRAN: 玉米/羊毛/棉花等交易所

Subsense.DEF: to give someone something and receive the same kind of thing from them at the same time
Subsense.EXAMPLE: We exchange gifts at Christmas.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们在圣诞节时交换礼物。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: At the end of the game, players traditionally exchange shirts with each other.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 按照传统﹐比赛结束时两队队员互换球衣。
Subsense.EXAMPLE: We exchanged phone numbers.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们交换了电话号码。

Subsense.DEF: to give someone something and receive something different from them

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Where can I exchange my dollars for pounds?
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我在哪里可以把美元兑换成英镑？

F2NBox.HEADING: REGISTER 语体
F2NBox.EXPL: In everyday British English, people usually say swap or, in everyday American English, trade , rather than exchange.
F2NBox.TRAN: 在日常英国英语中﹐人们一般说swap﹐在日常美国英语中一般说trade﹐而不说exchange
F2NBox.EXAMPLE: Do you want to swap ( BrE 【英】 )/ trade ( AmE 【美】 )seats with me?
F2NBox.EXAMPLETRAN: 你想和我换座位吗？

Sense.DEF: to replace one thing with another

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He exchanged the black jacket for a blue one.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他把那件黑夹克换成了蓝色的。

Sense.DEF: if two people exchange words, looks etc, they talk to each other, look at each other etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: Until this evening I had never so much as exchanged a word with him.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 在今天晚上之前﹐我甚至连一句话都未跟他说过。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The two women exchanged glances and laughed.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那两个女子交换一下眼色﹐笑了起来。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I went over and exchanged greetings with everyone.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我走过去跟大家打招呼。

Sense.DEF: if two people exchange blows, they hit each other
to discuss something or share information, ideas etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: It’s a place where people can chat and exchange ideas.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 在这个地方人们可以聊天和交流想法。

Sense.DEF: to complete the final stage of buying a house by signing a contract with the person you are buying it from
Sense.TRAN: 〔与卖方签署并〕交换购房契约

Sense.DEF: the value of the money of one country compared to the money of another country
Sense.EXAMPLE: a more favourable exchange rate
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 更优惠的汇率

Sense.DEF: a system for controlling the exchange rate between the money of one country and that of another
a student who goes to a foreign country to study, usually as a part of a programme
Sense.EXAMPLE: an 18-year-old exchange student from France
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 来自法国的18岁交换生

Sense.DEF: the British government department that is responsible for collecting taxes and paying out public money
the government tax that is put on the goods that are produced and used inside a country

GramExa.GLOSS: someone who collects excise
the money paid as excise
GramExa.EXAMPLE: excise duty on tobacco
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 烟草消费税

Sense.DEF: to remove or get rid of something, especially by cutting it out
Sense.EXAMPLE: The tumour was excised.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 肿瘤被切除了。

Sense.DEF: becoming excited too easily
Sense.EXAMPLE: A puppy is naturally affectionate and excitable.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 小狗生性热情好激动。

Sense.DEF: to make someone feel happy, interested, or eager
Sense.EXAMPLE: His playing is technically brilliant, but it doesn’t excite me.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他的演奏技巧娴熟﹐但并不让我激动。

Sense.DEF: to cause a particular feeling or reaction

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The court case has excited a lot of public interest.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这场官司引起了公众的极大兴趣。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: He tried not to do anything to excite the suspicion of the police.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他尽量不做会引起警方怀疑的事。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The book excited very little comment.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这本书并未引起多大反响。

Sense.DEF: to make someone feel sexual desire
to make an organ, nerve etc in your body react or increase its activity
Sense.TRAN: 使〔身体器官﹑神经等〕活动

Sense.DEF: happy, interested, or hopeful because something good has happened or will happen
Sense.EXAMPLE: Steve flies home tomorrow – we’re all really excited.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 史蒂夫明天坐飞机回家——我们都非常激动。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Maria’s starting to get pretty excited about the wedding.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 玛丽亚开始对婚礼感到十分兴奋。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: We’re all excited by the prospect of a party.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 想到要举行一场聚会﹐我们都很兴奋。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Michelle sounded excited to hear from him.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 米歇尔收到他的信好像很兴奋。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I’m so excited that we’re going to New York.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们要去纽约了﹐我很兴奋。

Sense.EXAMPLE: The food was nothing to get excited about not very good or special.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 食物很一般﹐没什么特别。
Sense.EXAMPLE: excited crowds of shoppers
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 兴奋的购物人群

Sense.DEF: very nervous and upset about something so that you cannot relax

GramExa.EXAMPLE: There’s no point getting excited about it. We can’t change things.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 没必要紧张﹐我们改变不了什么。

Sense.DEF: feeling sexual desire

RunOn.EXAMPLE: People had gathered and were talking excitedly.
RunOn.EXAMPLETRAN: 人们聚集在一起﹐兴奋地交谈着。

Exponent.DEF: feeling happy, especially about something good that has happened or is going to happen
Exponent.TRAN: 〔尤指对业已或即将发生的好事〕兴奋的﹐激动的
Exponent.EXAMPLE: He’s excited about his new job.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 他对自己的新工作感到兴奋。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The kids always get excited on their birthday.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 小孩子过生日总是很兴奋。

Exponent.DEF: very excited and pleased
Exponent.TRAN: 非常激动的﹐十分兴奋的
Exponent.EXAMPLE: She was thrilled to hear that you were in London.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 听说你在伦敦﹐她非常激动。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: I was thrilled when they told me that I’d got a place on the course.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们跟我说我得到了修读课程的名额﹐我欣喜若狂。

Exponent.DEF: very excited and full of energy, especially because you are experiencing something new or something that involves risks
Exponent.TRAN: 〔尤因正在经历新事物或需要冒险的事物而〕兴高采烈的﹐异常兴奋的
Exponent.EXAMPLE: She felt exhilarated by her new freedom.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 她为新获自由而激动不已。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The climb left him feeling exhilarated.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 那次登山让他感到兴奋不已。

Exponent.DEF: to feel excited about something good that is going to happen and to think about it a lot
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The kids are looking forward to their vacation – they’ve never been to California before.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 孩子们盼望着这次假期——他们从未去过加利福尼亚。

Exponent.DEF: to be very excited about something good that is going to happen
Exponent.EXAMPLE: I can’t wait to see him again.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 我迫不及待地想再见到他。

Exponent.EXP: on the edge of your seat
Exponent.DEF: extremely excited and interested when you are watching a film, game etc, because you do not know what is going to happen next
Exponent.TRAN: 〔观看电影﹑比赛等时因悬念而〕异常激动
Exponent.EXAMPLE: I was on the edge of my seat throughout the movie.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 这部电影从头至尾都扣人心弦﹐我在整个观看过程中一直很激动。

Exponent.DEF: very excited and nervous because you are waiting to find out what has happened
Exponent.TRAN: 〔因等待揭晓所发生之事而〕紧张不安
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Don’t keep us on tenterhooks! Did you pass your test?
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 别让我们着急啦！你测验及格了吗？

Sense.DEF: the feeling of being excited

GramExa.EXAMPLE: the excitement of becoming a parent
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 初为人父[母]的激动

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The children were filled with excitement at the thought of visiting Disneyland.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 想到要去迪士尼乐园﹐孩子们激动不已。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: In all the excitement, I left my wallet behind.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我一时激动﹐忘了拿钱包。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: In his excitement he couldn’t remember her name.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他激动得想不起她的名字了。

Sense.DEF: an exciting event or situation
Sense.EXAMPLE: We were both new to the excitements of life in the big city.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们俩都是初次感受大城市多姿多彩的生活。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: The arrival of a stranger caused some excitement in the village.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 一个陌生人的到来在村里引起了些许骚动。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: He tried to hide his excitement, but his voice was shaking.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 他试图掩饰自己的激动﹐但声音却在颤抖。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: She could hardly control her excitement when I told her the news.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 我把消息告诉她时﹐她几乎无法抑制激动之情。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: to be shaking slightly because you are so excited
Collocate.EXAMPLE: Her hands were trembling with excitement as she opened the letter.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 她打开信时激动得双手颤抖。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: it increases
Collocate.EXAMPLE: Her excitement grew as the day of the wedding came nearer.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 随着婚礼临近﹐她越来越兴奋。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: it gradually becomes less
people stop feeling excited

Collocate.EXAMPLE: There is great excitement about the Pope’s visit.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 教皇的到访令人们大为激动。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: The children waited with growing excitement.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 孩子们越等越兴奋。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: a very strong feeling of excitement
Collocate.EXAMPLE: Nothing can beat driving a racing car for sheer excitement.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 没有比开赛车更刺激的了。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: a very strong feeling of excitement

Collocate.COLLOCTRAN: 年轻人的/孩子般的兴奋

Collocate.EXAMPLE: They were full of excitement at the thought of meeting a real movie star.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 想到要见一位真正的电影明星﹐他们就满心激动。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: He woke up that morning with a feeling of excitement.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 那天早晨他醒来时情绪亢奋。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: It seemed that the whole country was in a state of excitement.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 似乎全国上下都处于兴奋状态。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: a general feeling of excitement among a group of people
Collocate.EXAMPLE: There was a real air of excitement before the game.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 比赛开始前气氛非常热烈。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: a sudden feeling of excitement
an occasion when there is suddenly a lot of excitement about something
a feeling of excitement that spreads through a group of people
a feeling of excitement that lasts a very short time

Sense.DEF: making you feel excited
Sense.TRAN: 令人兴奋的﹔使人激动的﹔刺激的
Sense.EXAMPLE: an exciting discovery
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 激动人心的发现
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘Julia and Paul are getting married!’ ‘Oh, how exciting!’
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “朱莉娅和保罗要结婚了！”“啊﹐太让人兴奋了！”
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’ve got some very exciting news for you.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我给你带来了一些很激动人心的消息。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Let’s do something exciting.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们来做些让人振奋的事情吧。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Melanie finds her work exciting and rewarding.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 梅拉妮觉得自己的工作既刺激又有意义。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: exciting job opportunities
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 令人兴奋的就业机会

RunOn.EXAMPLE: the most excitingly original movie of the year
RunOn.EXAMPLETRAN: 年度最刺激的原创电影

Exponent.DEF: very exciting
a gripping film, story etc is very exciting and interesting
Exponent.TRAN: 〔电影﹑故事等〕扣人心弦的﹐引人入胜的

Exponent.DEF: used about something that is exciting to watch or hear about as it happens
Exponent.TRAN: 〔从视觉或听觉上〕给人深刻印象的﹔激动人心的
Exponent.EXAMPLE: the dramatic events of the past week
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 过去一周发生的震撼人心的事件

Exponent.DEF: making you feel happy, excited, and full of energy
Exponent.TRAN: 使人兴高采烈的﹔令人激动的
Exponent.EXAMPLE: an exhilarating ride
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 令人兴奋的旅程

Exponent.DEF: very exciting, especially because you do not know what is going to happen next
Exponent.TRAN: 充满悬念的﹔非常刺激的
Exponent.EXAMPLE: a nail-biting finish
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 扣人心弦的结尾

Sense.DEF: to say something suddenly and loudly because you are surprised, angry, or excited
Sense.TRAN: 〔因惊讶﹑愤怒或兴奋而〕呼喊﹐惊叫
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘No!’ she exclaimed in shock.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “不！”她惊呼道。

Sense.DEF: a sound, word, or short sentence that you say suddenly and loudly because you are surprised, angry, or excited

GramExa.EXAMPLE: horrified exclamations of disgust
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 厌恶的惊叫

Sense.DEF: the mark (!) that you write after a sentence or word that expresses surprise, anger, or excitement
to deliberately not include something
Sense.EXAMPLE: a special diet that excludes dairy products
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 不包含奶制品的特别食谱
Sense.EXAMPLE: The judges decided to exclude evidence which had been unfairly attained.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 法官裁决不接纳以不正当手段获取的证据。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Some of the data was specifically excluded from the report.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这篇报道特意不采用部分数据。

F2NBox.HEADING: REGISTER 语体
F2NBox.EXPL: In everyday English, people usually say leave something or someone out rather than exclude something or someone.
F2NBox.TRAN: 在日常英语中﹐人们一般说leave something/someone out﹐而不说exclude something/someone
F2NBox.EXAMPLE: Some information was left out of the report.
F2NBox.EXAMPLETRAN: 有些消息报道中并没有提到。
F2NBox.EXAMPLE: We didn’t mean to leave you out .
F2NBox.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们并非故意把你遗漏的。

Sense.DEF: to not allow someone to take part in something or not allow them to enter a place, especially in a way that seems wrong or unfair
Sense.TRAN: 〔尤指以看起来错误或不公正的方式〕不准…参与﹔不准…进入﹔排斥〔某人〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: a mainstream exhibition that excluded women artists
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 排斥女艺术家的主流展览

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The press had been deliberately excluded from the event.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这一活动有意不让记者参与。

Sense.EXAMPLE: Sarah heard the other girls talking and laughing and felt excluded.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 萨拉听见其他女孩又说又笑﹐觉得自己受到了排斥。

Sense.DEF: to officially make a child leave their school because of their bad behaviour
to decide that something is not a possibility
Sense.TRAN: 认为…不可能﹔排除…的可能性
Sense.EXAMPLE: Social workers have excluded sexual abuse as a reason for the child’s disappearance.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 对于这个孩子的失踪原因﹐社会福利工作者排除了遭受性虐待的可能性。
Sense.EXAMPLE: At this stage we cannot entirely exclude the possibility of staff cuts.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 到了这个阶段﹐我们不能完全排除裁员的可能性。

Sense.DEF: not including – used especially when you are making a list or calculating a total
Sense.TRAN: 不包括﹐除去〔尤用于列出清单或计算总数时〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: Television is watched in 97 per cent of American homes (excluding Alaska and Hawaii).
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 在美国﹐97%的家庭收看电视(不包括阿拉斯加和夏威夷)。

Sense.DEF: when someone is not allowed to take part in something or enter a place

GramExa.EXAMPLE: the country’s exclusion from the United Nations
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 该国被排除在联合国之外

Sense.DEF: when a child is officially made to leave their school because of their bad behaviour

Sense.LEXUNIT: do sth to the exclusion of sth
Sense.DEF: to do something so much that you do not do, include, or have time for other things
Sense.TRAN: 专注于做某事而排斥[无暇顾及]其他事情
Sense.EXAMPLE: Your essays tend to concentrate on one theme to the exclusion of everything else.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你的文章往往会集中于一个主题而不顾及其他各个方面。

Sense.DEF: something that is excluded from a contract
Sense.EXAMPLE: You will be sent full details of the exclusions of your insurance policy.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 届时会将保险单不予承保的项目的具体说明给你寄去。

Sense.DEF: an area that people are not allowed to enter because it is dangerous or because secret things happen there
Sense.EXAMPLE: the military exclusion zone
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 军事禁区

Sense.DEF: available or belonging only to particular people, and not shared

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Our figure skating club has exclusive use of the rink on Mondays.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 溜冰场每逢星期一专供我们的花样滑冰俱乐部使用。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Tune in to our exclusive coverage of Wimbledon.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 请收看我们对温布尔登网球锦标赛的独家报道。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: This offer is exclusive to readers of ‘The Sun’.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这是《太阳报》读者独享的优惠。

Sense.DEF: exclusive places, organizations, clothes etc are so expensive that not many people can afford to use or buy them
Sense.EXAMPLE: Bel Air is an exclusive suburb of Los Angeles.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 贝莱尔是洛杉矶郊外一处高级住宅区。
Sense.EXAMPLE: an exclusive girls’ school
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 贵族女子学校

Sense.DEF: deliberately not allowing someone to do something or be part of a group
Sense.TRAN: 排外的﹔不准加入某团体的
Sense.EXAMPLE: a racially exclusive hiring policy
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 种族排外的聘用政策

Sense.DEF: if two things are mutually exclusive, you cannot have or do both of them
Sense.TRAN: 相互排斥的﹐互不相容的
Sense.EXAMPLE: Lesbianism and motherhood are not mutually exclusive.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 女性的同性恋倾向和母亲身份并不相互排斥。

Sense.DEF: not including something
Sense.EXAMPLE: Our prices are exclusive of sales tax.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们的价格不包括销售税。

Sense.DEF: concerned with only one thing
Sense.EXAMPLE: The committee’s exclusive focus will be to improve public transportation.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 委员会关注的唯一焦点将是改善公共交通运输。

Sense.DEF: an important or exciting story that is printed in only one newspaper, because that newspaper was the first to find out about it
Sense.EXAMPLE: a New York Post exclusive about the Kennedy marriage
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 《纽约邮报》有关肯尼迪婚事的独家报道

Sense.DEF: only
Sense.EXAMPLE: This offer is available exclusively to people who call now.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 只有现在打来电话的人才能享有这个优惠。

Sense.DEF: to punish someone by no longer allowing them to be a member of the Roman Catholic church
a criminal who has been in prison but who is now free
Sense.TRAN: 坐过牢的人﹐蹲过监狱的人

Sense.DEF: to express a very bad opinion of a book, play etc
Sense.TRAN: 严厉批评﹐痛斥〔书﹑戏剧等〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: an excoriating review in ‘The Times’
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 《泰晤士报》刊登的一篇措辞严厉的评论

Sense.DEF: the solid waste material that you get rid of through your bowels
something that is bad, unnecessary, or ugly — used to show disapproval
Sense.EXAMPLE: The new museum is nothing but an excrescence on the urban landscape.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 新博物馆纯粹是市区景观的一处败笔。

Sense.DEF: an ugly growth on an animal or plant
the solid or liquid waste material that people and animals produce and get rid of from their bodies
to get rid of waste material from your body through your bowels, your skin etc
the process of getting rid of waste material from your body
the waste material that people or animals get rid of from their bodies
extremely painful
Sense.EXAMPLE: When I bend my arm, the pain is excruciating.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我弯胳膊时疼得简直受不了。

Sense.DEF: if something is excruciating, it is extremely unpleasant, for example because it is boring or embarrassing
Sense.EXAMPLE: Helen described the events of the night before in excruciating detail.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 海伦絮絮叨叨地描述了前一天晚上发生的事﹐令人不胜其烦。

Sense.DEF: to prove that someone is not guilty of something
a short journey arranged so that a group of people can visit a place, especially while they are on holiday
Sense.TRAN: 〔尤指集体度假时的〕短途旅行

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Included in the tour is an excursion to the Grand Canyon.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这次旅游包括大峡谷观光。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: We went on an excursion to the Pyramids.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们去金字塔游玩了。

Sense.DEF: a short journey made for a particular purpose
Sense.EXAMPLE: a shopping excursion
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 购物游

Sense.DEF: an attempt to experience or learn about something that is new to you
Sense.EXAMPLE: the company’s excursion into new markets
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 公司涉足新的市场

Sense.DEF: behaviour that is excusable can be forgiven
Sense.EXAMPLE: an excusable reaction of anger
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 情有可原的恼怒反应

Subsense.DEF: used when you want to get someone’s attention politely, especially when you want to ask a question
Subsense.TRAN: 劳驾〔用于礼貌地引起他人注意﹐尤其是发问时〕
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Excuse me, can you tell me the way to the museum please?
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 劳驾﹐请问去博物馆怎么走？

Subsense.DEF: used to say that you are sorry for doing something rude or embarrassing
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Oh, excuse me. I didn’t know anyone was here.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 噢﹐对不起﹐我不知道这里有人。

Subsense.DEF: used to ask someone politely to move so that you can walk past
Subsense.TRAN: 借光﹐借过〔用于礼貌地请求别人让路〕
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Excuse me, could I just squeeze past?
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 借光﹐请让我过去一下好吗？

Subsense.DEF: used to politely tell someone that you are leaving a place
Subsense.TRAN: 抱歉〔用于礼貌地表示要离开〕
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Excuse me a moment. I’ll be right back.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 抱歉﹐我失陪一会儿﹐马上就回来。

Subsense.DEF: used when you disagree with someone but want to be polite about it
Subsense.TRAN: 请原谅〔用于礼貌地表示反对〕
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Excuse me, but I don’t think that’s what he meant at all.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 请原谅﹐不过我认为他绝对不是这个意思。

Subsense.DEF: used to show that you disagree with someone or are very surprised or upset by what they have just said
Subsense.TRAN: 请原谅﹐很抱歉〔用于表示不同意某人的意见或对其所说的话感到意外或不快〕
Subsense.EXAMPLE: ‘You’re going to pay, right?’ ‘Excuse me?’
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: “你来付钱﹐对吗？”“你说什么？”

Subsense.DEF: used to ask someone to repeat something that they have just said
Subsense.EXAMPLE: ‘What time is it?’ ‘Excuse me?’ ‘I asked you what time it is.’
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: “现在几点了？”“对不起﹐你说什么？”“我问你现在几点了。

Sense.DEF: to forgive someone for doing something that is not seriously wrong, such as being rude or careless
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’ll excuse you this time, but don’t be late again.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这次我原谅你﹐但别再迟到了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Please excuse my bad handwriting.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 请原谅﹐我的字写得不好。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Please excuse me for being so late today.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 请原谅﹐我今天来得太晚了。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Smith can be excused for his lack of interest in the course his lack of interest is reasonable.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 史密斯对这门课不感兴趣是情有可原的。

F2NBox.HEADING: REGISTER 语体
F2NBox.EXPL: In informal situations, people often say sorry about ... , sorry for doing ... or sorry I ... rather than asking someone to excuse something.
F2NBox.TRAN: 在非正式的场合中﹐人们常说 sorry about ...﹐sorry for doing ... 或sorry I...﹐而不说请某人excuse something
F2NBox.EXAMPLE: Sorry about my handwriting.
F2NBox.EXAMPLETRAN: 对不起﹐我的字写得不好。
F2NBox.EXAMPLE: Sorry for being so late. OR 或 Sorry I’m so late.
F2NBox.EXAMPLETRAN: 对不起﹐我来得太晚了。

Sense.DEF: to allow someone not to do something that they are supposed to do

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Can I be excused from swimming today? I have a cold.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我今天能不游泳吗？我感冒了。

Sense.DEF: to be or give a good reason for someone’s careless or offensive behaviour
Sense.EXAMPLE: Nothing can excuse that kind of rudeness.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 什么也无法为那种粗鲁行为开脱。

Sense.DEF: to give someone permission to leave a place
Sense.EXAMPLE: May I please be excused from the table?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我可以离开饭桌了吗？

Sense.DEF: to say politely that you need to leave a place
Sense.EXAMPLE: Richard excused himself and went to his room.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 理查德礼貌地告辞﹐到自己的房间去了。

Sense.DEF: used when someone has offended you or told you that you have done something wrong
a reason that you give to explain careless or offensive behaviour

GramExa.EXAMPLE: What’s your excuse for being late this time?
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 你迟到了﹐这次又是什么理由？

Sense.EXAMPLE: I’m tired of listening to his excuses.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我听厌了他的种种理由。

Sense.DEF: a reason that you invent to explain an action and to hide your real intentions

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I need an excuse to call her.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我给她打电话需要有个借口。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The conference is just an excuse for a holiday in New York.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个会议不过是个去纽约度假的借口。

Sense.LEXUNIT: there is no excuse for sth
Sense.DEF: used to say that someone’s behaviour is too bad to be explained or accepted
Sense.EXAMPLE: There is no excuse for such rudeness.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这种无礼行为实在说不过去。

Sense.DEF: to explain why you are not able to do something
Sense.EXAMPLE: Please make my excuses at the meeting tomorrow.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 请在明天的会上替我解释一下不能到会的原因。

Sense.LEXUNIT: a poor/rotten etc excuse for sth
Sense.DEF: used when you think someone or something is very bad
Sense.EXAMPLE: He’s a rotten excuse for a lawyer. Why on earth did you hire him?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他是个极糟糕的律师﹐你到底为什么雇用他？

Sense.DEF: a note written by your doctor or one of your parents saying that you were ill on a particular day

ColloBox.HEADING: COLLOCATIONS 词语搭配 – MEANINGS 义项 1 & 2

Collocate.EXAMPLE: I made up some excuse about my car breaking down.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 我编了个借口﹐说我的车抛锚了。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: give reasons which try to explain why someone has made a mistake or behaved badly
Collocate.EXAMPLE: His mother was always making excuses for her son’s behaviour.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 他妈妈总是为儿子的行为找借口。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: She never complained or used her illness as an excuse.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 她从不抱怨﹐也不拿自己的病当借口。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: I began to look for excuses to avoid seeing him.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 我开始寻找种种借口﹐避免和他见面。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: I’ll have to give my boss some kind of excuse.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 我总得给我老板一个理由。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: She didn’t believe his excuse for one minute.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 她压根儿不相信他的借口。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: Companies have no excuse for breaking the law.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 公司没有任何理由违反法律。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: A sunny day is a good excuse to go to the beach.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 天气晴朗就应该到海滩去。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: one that other people will believe
Collocate.COLLOCTRAN: 可以接受的/说得过去的理由
Collocate.EXAMPLE: If your train was cancelled, that is a perfectly reasonable excuse.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 要是你那班火车被取消了﹐那可就是个再好不过的理由。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: one that is true and that other people cannot criticize
Collocate.EXAMPLE: He didn’t have a legitimate excuse for being late.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 他迟到了﹐没有正当的理由。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: The phone call gave me the perfect excuse to leave.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个电话正好让我有借口离开。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: one that is difficult to believe
Collocate.EXAMPLE: Joe muttered some feeble excuse about having a headache.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 乔嘟嘟哝哝地搪塞说他头痛。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: very weak
Collocate.COLLOCTRAN: 牵强的/站不住脚的借口

Collocate.COLLOC: the usual excuse/the same old excuse
Collocate.COLLOCTRAN: 惯常的借口/老一套借口

Collocate.COLLOC: use every excuse in the book
Collocate.COLLGLOSS: use every possible excuse
Collocate.EXAMPLE: He used every excuse in the book to avoid seeing the doctor.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 他千方百计找借口不去看病。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: for any reason, however unimportant
Collocate.EXAMPLE: She comes to our house at the slightest excuse.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 她动不动就借故到我们家来。

Sense.DEF: a person or telephone number that is ex-directory is not in the public telephone book
Sense.TRAN: 〔人或电话号码〕未列入电话号码簿的
Sense.EXAMPLE: The number is ex-directory.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 该号码未列入电话号码簿。
Sense.EXAMPLE: After several threatening calls, we decided to go ex-directory.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 接到几个恐吓电话后﹐我们决定不再将号码列入电话号码簿了。

Sense.DEF: an informal word for executive
extremely bad
to express strong disapproval or hatred for someone or something
a computer file that can be run as a program
to kill someone, especially legally as a punishment

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Thousands have been executed for political crimes.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 数以千计的人因政治罪而被处死了。

Sense.EXAMPLE: 13 people were summarily executed killed without any trial or legal process by the guerrillas.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 有13人被游击队员就地处决。

Sense.DEF: to do something that has been carefully planned
Sense.EXAMPLE: The job involves drawing up and executing a plan of nursing care.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这项工作包括拟订和实施一个护理计划。

Sense.DEF: to perform a difficult action or movement

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The skaters’ routine was perfectly executed.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 滑冰选手把整套动作完成得非常出色。

Sense.DEF: if a computer executes a program or commandinstruction, it makes the program or command happen or work
Sense.TRAN: 执行〔计算机程序或指令〕

Sense.DEF: to make sure that the instructions in a legal document are followed
to produce a painting, book, film etc
Sense.TRAN: 创作〔绘画﹑文字﹑电影作品等〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: a boldly executed story
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 大胆创作的故事

Sense.DEF: when someone is killed, especially as a legal punishment
Sense.EXAMPLE: a public execution
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 当众处死
Sense.EXAMPLE: The two men face execution They will be killed as a punishment.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 两名男子面临处决。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Torture and summary execution execution without a trial or any legal process are common.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 严刑拷打和不经审判就地处决相当普遍。
Sense.EXAMPLE: He was granted a stay of execution delay in carrying out an execution.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他被准予缓期处决。

Sense.DEF: a process in which you do something that has been carefully planned

GramExa.EXAMPLE: the formulation and execution of urban policy
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 城市政策的制定与实施

Sense.DEF: the process of making sure that the instructions in a legal document are followed
Sense.EXAMPLE: the execution of a will
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 遗嘱的执行

Sense.DEF: the performance of a difficult action or movement
the process of producing something such as a painting, film, book etc, or the way it is produced
Sense.TRAN: 〔绘画﹑电影﹑文字作品等的〕创作(方式)
Sense.EXAMPLE: art that is unusual in design and execution
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 在设计和创作方面与众不同的艺术

Sense.DEF: when you make a computer program work, or a commandinstruction happen
someone whose job is to execute criminals
a manager in an organization or company who helps make important decisions
Sense.EXAMPLE: a marketing executive
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 营销主管

GramExa.EXAMPLE: top executives on high salaries
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 领取高薪的高层主管

Sense.DEF: the part of a government that makes sure decisions and laws work well
a group of people who are in charge of an organization and make the rules
Sense.EXAMPLE: the union’s executive
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 工会的领导层

Sense.DEF: relating to the job of managing a business or organization and making decisions
Sense.EXAMPLE: a commission with executive powers
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 有执行权的委员会

GramExa.GLOSS: a group of people who have the power to make decisions

Sense.DEF: for the use of people who have important jobs in a company
Sense.EXAMPLE: the executive dining-room
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 管理人员饭厅

Sense.DEF: expensive and designed for people who earn a lot of money

GramExa.GLOSS: objects to play with at work

Sense.DEF: the right of a president or other government leader to keep official records and papers secret
Sense.TRAN: 行政特权﹐总统特权〔指总统或其他政府领导人对官方文件保密的特权〕

Sense.DEF: someone who deals with the instructions in someone’s will
a detailed explanation of a piece of writing, especially a religious piece of writing
Sense.TRAN: 〔尤指对宗教著作的〕诠释﹔解经

Sense.DEF: a good or typical example

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Milt’s career is an exemplar of survival in difficult times.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 米尔特的经历是在艰难时期求生存的典范。

Sense.DEF: excellent and providing a good example for people to follow
Sense.EXAMPLE: a company with an exemplary record on environmental issues
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 在处理环境问题方面可作为楷模的公司

Sense.DEF: an exemplary punishment is very severe and is intended to stop other people from committing the same crime
to be a very typical example of something
Sense.EXAMPLE: The building exemplifies the style of architecture which was popular at the time.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这栋大楼代表了当时流行的建筑风格。

Sense.DEF: to give an example of something
Sense.EXAMPLE: Problems are exemplified in the report.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 问题都在报告中作了举例说明。

Sense.DEF: not affected by something, or not having to do it or pay it
Sense.TRAN: 被免除(义务)的﹐获豁免的

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The interest is exempt from income tax.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 利息收入免征所得税。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Children are exempt from the charges.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 儿童免费。

Sense.DEF: to give someone permission not to do or pay something

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Charities are exempted from paying the tax.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 慈善团体免付这项税款。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: a document that exempts the owner from liability in case of accidents
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 发生事故时免除业主责任的文件

F2NBox.HEADING: REGISTER 语体
F2NBox.EXPL: In everyday British English, people usually say let sb off (doing) sth rather than exempt sb from (doing) sth .
F2NBox.TRAN: 在日常英国英语中﹐人们一般说let sb off (doing) sth﹐而不说exempt sb from (doing) sth
F2NBox.EXAMPLE: Living abroad doesn’t necessarily let you off paying tax.
F2NBox.EXAMPLETRAN: 在国外居住不一定可以不缴税。

Sense.DEF: an amount of money that you do not have to pay tax on
Sense.EXAMPLE: You qualify for a tax exemption on the loan.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你有资格获准贷款免税。

Sense.DEF: permission not to do or pay something that you would normally have to do or pay

GramExa.EXAMPLE: exemption from customs duties
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 免除关税

Sense.EXAMPLE: The commission granted temporary exemptions.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 委员会准予临时豁免。

Sense.DEF: physical activities that you do in order to stay healthy and become stronger
Sense.EXAMPLE: Try to fit some regular exercise into your daily routine.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 尽量在日常生活中安排一些经常性的锻炼。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Working in an office, I don’t get much exercise.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 由于在办公室工作﹐我很少运动。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Most people need to do more exercise.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 大多数人需要多锻炼。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Gentle exercise can be beneficial for older people.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 运动量不大的锻炼对年长者有益。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: After the operation, you should avoid strenuous exercise.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 手术之后﹐你应该避免剧烈运动。

Sense.DEF: a movement or set of movements that you do regularly to keep your body healthy
Sense.EXAMPLE: stretching exercises
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 伸展运动
Sense.EXAMPLE: You can do exercises to strengthen your stomach muscles.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你可以做体操来增强腹部肌肉。

Sense.DEF: an activity or process that helps you practise a particular skill
Sense.EXAMPLE: relaxation exercises
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 放松练习
Sense.EXAMPLE: role-play exercises
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 角色扮演练习

Sense.DEF: a set of questions in a book that test a student’s knowledge or skill
Sense.EXAMPLE: Do Exercises 3 and 4 on page 51 for homework.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 家庭作业是第51页上的练习3和4。

Sense.DEF: an activity or situation that has a particular quality or result
Sense.EXAMPLE: closing libraries as part of a cost-cutting exercise
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 关闭图书馆作为完成削减支出任务的途径之一
Sense.EXAMPLE: It’s a pointless exercise.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这是毫无意义的活动。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Buying a house can be an exercise in frustration.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 买房子有时是一桩让人头疼的事情。

Sense.DEF: a set of activities for training soldiers etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: a military exercise
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 军事演习

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Half the unit was away on exercise.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 分队有一半出去演习了。

Sense.DEF: the use of a power or right
Sense.EXAMPLE: the exercise of political leadership
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 政治领导权的行使

Collocate.EXAMPLE: He ought to do more exercise.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 他应该多锻炼。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: I don’t get enough exercise.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 我缺乏足够的运动。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: Swimming is very good exercise for your muscles.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 游泳是锻炼肌肉的极好运动。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: Taking regular exercise is the best way to improve your overall health.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 经常锻炼是改善整体健康状况的最佳方法。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: Physical exercise keeps you fit and helps to reduce stress.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 体育锻炼可以让人身体健康﹐并有助于减轻压力。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: involving a lot of physical effort
Collocate.EXAMPLE: Pregnant women should avoid strenuous exercise.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 孕妇应避免剧烈运动。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: not involving too much physical effort
Collocate.EXAMPLE: Try to do some gentle exercise as part of your daily routine.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 尽量每天都做些运动量不太大的运动。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: in which you breathe deeply and your heart beats faster

Collocate.EXAMPLE: This type of exercise is excellent for losing weight.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 这种锻炼方式极利于减肥。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: Children are becoming overweight through lack of exercise.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 儿童由于缺乏锻炼而开始超重。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: a plan that includes different types of exercise
Collocate.EXAMPLE: The athletes follow an intensive exercise programme.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 这些运动员正按照一项高强度的运动计划训练。

Sense.DEF: to use a power, right, or quality that you have
Sense.TRAN: 运用﹐行使〔权力﹑权利或自身特质〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: There are plans to encourage people to exercise their right to vote.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 有计划鼓励人们行使投票权。
Sense.EXAMPLE: People who can exercise some control over their surroundings feel less anxious.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 能够对周围环境有所控制的人不会太焦虑。

Sense.DEF: to do sports or physical activities in order to stay healthy and become stronger
Sense.EXAMPLE: It’s important to exercise regularly.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 经常锻炼很重要。

Sense.DEF: to make a particular part of your body move in order to make it stronger
Sense.EXAMPLE: Swimming exercises all the major muscle groups.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 游泳能使全身主要肌群都得到锻炼。

Sense.DEF: to make an animal walk or run in order to keep it healthy and strong
Sense.EXAMPLE: people exercising their dogs in the park
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 在公园里遛狗的人

Subsense.DEF: to make someone think about a subject or problem and consider how to deal with it
Subsense.TRAN: 使关注﹔使致力于〔解决问题〕
Subsense.EXAMPLE: It’s an issue that’s exercised the minds of scientists for a long time.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这是科学家长期关注并力求解决的问题。

Subsense.DEF: if something exercises someone, they think about it all the time and are very anxious or worried – often used humorously
Subsense.TRAN: 使焦虑﹔使不安〔常为幽默用法〕
Subsense.EXAMPLE: It was clear that Flavia had been exercised by this thought.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 显然这一想法令弗拉维娅坐立不安。

Sense.DEF: a bicycle that does not move and is used for exercising indoors
a book that students use for writing in
to use your power, influence etc in order to make something happen
Sense.EXAMPLE: They exerted considerable influence within the school.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们在校内施加了很大的影响力。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Environmental groups are exerting pressure on the government to tighten pollution laws.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 环境保护组织在向政府施加压力﹐要求从严执行环保法律法规。

Sense.DEF: to work very hard and use a lot of physical or mental energy
Sense.EXAMPLE: He has exerted himself tirelessly on behalf of the charity.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他为这个慈善组织奋斗不懈。

Sense.DEF: a lot of physical or mental effort
Sense.EXAMPLE: The afternoon’s exertions had left us feeling exhausted.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 下午太劳累了﹐我们感到精疲力竭。
Sense.EXAMPLE: mental exertion
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 费心思

Sense.DEF: the use of power, influence etc to make something happen
Sense.EXAMPLE: the exertion of authority
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 行使权力

Sense.DEF: a word written in the instructions of a play to tell two or more actors to leave the stage
Sense.TRAN: 〔剧本中的舞台指示﹐两个或两个以上演员〕退场﹐下场

Sense.DEF: to remove dead cells from your skin in order to make it smoother
an ex gratia payment is one that is made as a gift, and not as a legal duty
Sense.TRAN: 作为礼物的〔非出于法律义务〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: an ex gratia payment of £15,000
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 15,000英镑的特惠款项

Sense.DEF: to breathe air, smoke etc out of your mouth
Sense.EXAMPLE: Take a deep breath, then exhale slowly.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 深吸一口气﹐然后慢慢呼出。

Sense.DEF: to make someone feel extremely tired
Sense.EXAMPLE: A full day’s teaching exhausts me.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 讲一整天课令我精疲力竭。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He’d exhausted himself carrying all the boxes upstairs.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他把所有的箱子搬到楼上﹐把自己弄得精疲力竭。

Sense.DEF: to use all of something
Sense.EXAMPLE: We are in danger of exhausting the world’s oil supply.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们面临世界石油储备耗尽的危险。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Having exhausted all other possibilities, I asked Jan to look after the baby.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 各种可能的办法都行不通了﹐我只好请简来照料宝宝。

Sense.DEF: to talk about something so much that you have nothing more to say about it
Sense.TRAN: 详尽无遗地论述某主题/话题等
Sense.EXAMPLE: Once we’d exhausted the subject of Jill’s wedding, I didn’t know what to say.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们把吉尔婚礼的每个细节都聊遍之后﹐我就不知道该说些什么了。

Sense.DEF: a pipe on a car or machine that waste gases pass through
the gas produced when an engine is working
Sense.EXAMPLE: exhaust fumes
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 排出的废气

Sense.DEF: extremely tired
Sense.TRAN: 筋疲力尽的﹐疲惫不堪的
Sense.EXAMPLE: You look absolutely exhausted.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你看上去一副疲惫不堪的样子。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I was exhausted by the journey.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 旅途使我筋疲力尽。

F2NBox.HEADING: REGISTER 语体
F2NBox.EXPL: In everyday English, people often say worn out rather than exhausted.
F2NBox.TRAN: 在日常英语中﹐人们常说worn out﹐而不说exhausted
F2NBox.EXAMPLE: You look worn out.
F2NBox.EXAMPLETRAN: 你看上去累坏了。

Sense.DEF: having or containing no more of a particular thing or substance
Sense.EXAMPLE: an exhausted coal mine
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 矿源枯竭的煤矿

Sense.DEF: making you feel extremely tired
Sense.EXAMPLE: an exhausting process
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 令人精疲力竭的过程
Sense.EXAMPLE: It had been an exhausting day.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那一天令人疲惫不堪。

Sense.DEF: extreme tiredness

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He collapsed with exhaustion.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他累垮了。

Sense.EXAMPLE: Sheer exhaustion forced him to give up.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他疲惫不堪﹐只好放弃。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Many runners were suffering from heat exhaustion when you become tired and ill because you are too hot.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 许多赛跑运动员都出现了热衰竭。

GramExa.GLOSS: when you become ill because you have been working too hard or have been very worried
GramExa.COLLOTRAN: 〔因过度劳累或担忧而引起的〕神经衰弱

Sense.DEF: when all of something has been used

GramExa.EXAMPLE: the exhaustion of oil supplies
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 石油储备的枯竭

Sense.DEF: extremely thorough and complete
Sense.EXAMPLE: an exhaustive investigation
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 彻底的调查
Sense.EXAMPLE: The list is by no means exhaustive.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 清单一点也不详尽。

Sense.DEF: to show something in a public place so that people can go to see it
Sense.EXAMPLE: Her paintings have been exhibited all over the world.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她的绘画作品在世界各地展出。

Sense.DEF: to clearly show a particular quality, emotion, or ability
Sense.TRAN: 展示﹐显示〔品质﹑情感或能力〕

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a patient who is exhibiting classic symptoms of mental illness
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 显现出精神病典型症状的患者

Sense.DEF: something, for example a painting, that is put in a public place so that people can go to see it
Sense.EXAMPLE: The exhibits date from the 17th century.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这些展品的历史可以追溯到17世纪。

Sense.DEF: an object that is shown in court to prove whether someone is guilty or not
Sense.EXAMPLE: Exhibit A is the hammer found next to the victim.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 证物甲是在受害者身边发现的一把锤子。

Sense.DEF: an exhibition
Sense.EXAMPLE: a big exhibit in Milan
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 在米兰举办的大型展览会

Sense.DEF: a show of paintings, photographs, or other objects that people can go to see

GramExa.EXAMPLE: an exhibition of black and white photographs
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 黑白摄影作品展

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The museum is staging an exhibition of Picasso’s work.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 博物馆正举办毕加索画展。

Sense.DEF: when something such as a painting is shown in a public place

GramExa.EXAMPLE: She never agreed to the public exhibition of her sculptures while she was still alive.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她生前从未同意公开展出自己的雕塑作品。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: A collection of paintings by David Hockney is on exhibition at the Museum of Art.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 大卫·霍克尼的一批绘画作品正在美术馆展出。

Sense.DEF: a situation in which someone shows a particular skill, feeling, or type of behaviour
Sense.TRAN: 〔某种技能﹑感情或行为的〕表现﹐显露
Sense.EXAMPLE: I’ve never seen such an exhibition of jealousy.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我从未见过如此嫉妒的表现。

Sense.DEF: to behave in a silly or embarrassing way
behaviour that is intended to make people notice or admire you – used to show disapproval
a medical condition that makes someone want to show their sexual organs in public places
someone who likes to make other people notice them – often used to show disapproval
someone who has a medical condition that makes them want to show their sexual organs in public places
Sense.TRAN: 有露阴癖者﹔有裸露癖者

Sense.DEF: a person or company who is showing their work or products to the public
Sense.EXAMPLE: an exhibitor at a trade show
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 商品展销会上的参展商

Sense.DEF: to make someone feel very excited and happy
Sense.TRAN: 使兴高采烈﹐使感到激动

Sense.DEF: feeling extremely happy, excited, and full of energy
Sense.TRAN: 兴高采烈的﹐异常兴奋的
Sense.EXAMPLE: Dan felt strangely exhilarated by the day’s events.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 那天发生的事情使丹感到异常兴奋。

Sense.DEF: making you feel happy, excited, and full of energy
Sense.TRAN: 使人兴高采烈的﹔令人激动的
Sense.EXAMPLE: an exhilarating experience
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 刺激的经历
Sense.EXAMPLE: an exhilarating walk
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 让人精神焕发的散步

Sense.DEF: a feeling of being happy, excited, and full of energy

GramExa.EXAMPLE: She enjoyed the exhilaration of jet-skiing.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她喜欢玩喷气式滑艇带来的快感。

Sense.DEF: to try very hard to persuade someone to do something

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Police exhorted the crowd to remain calm.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 警察极力劝说群众保持镇静。

Sense.DEF: to remove a dead body from the ground, especially in order to check the cause of death
Sense.TRAN: 〔尤指为验尸而从墓内〕掘出〔尸体〕

Sense.DEF: the things you must do in order to deal with a difficult or urgent situation

GramExa.EXAMPLE: the exigencies of war
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 战争的应急措施

Sense.DEF: demanding a lot of attention from other people in a way that is unreasonable
an exigent situation is urgent, so that you must deal with it very quickly
very small in amount
Sense.EXAMPLE: exiguous earnings
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 微薄的收入

Sense.DEF: a situation in which you are forced to leave your country and live in another country, especially for political reasons
Sense.TRAN: 〔尤指出于政治原因的〕流亡国外

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a writer now living in exile
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 现正过着流亡生活的作家

Sense.EXAMPLE: He went into exile to escape political imprisonment.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他为了逃避政治监禁而流亡国外。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The house was raided and the family was forced into exile.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 房子被抄﹐全家人被迫流亡。

Sense.EXAMPLE: He spent many years in enforced exile.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他被强制流放了许多年。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: She had been in voluntary exile since 1990.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她从1990年起一直自愿流亡。

Sense.DEF: someone who has been forced to live in exile
Sense.EXAMPLE: political exiles
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 政治流亡者

Sense.DEF: to force someone to leave their country, especially for political reasons
Sense.TRAN: 〔尤指出于政治原因而〕放逐﹐流放〔某人〕

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Several of the leaders were arrested and exiled to France.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 好几位领导人被逮捕并流放至法国。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a dictator who was exiled from his home country
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 被流放异乡的独裁者

Sense.EXAMPLE: the exiled former president
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 流亡国外的前总统

Sense.DEF: to happen or be present in a particular situation or place
Sense.EXAMPLE: The custom of arranged marriages still exists in many countries.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 许多国家仍存在包办婚姻的习俗。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Opportunities exist for students to gain sponsorship.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 学生有机会获得资助。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Stop pretending that the problem doesn’t exist.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 别再假装这个问题不存在了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The club will cease to exist if financial help is not found.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 该俱乐部要是得不到资助将不复存在。

Sense.DEF: to be real or alive
Sense.EXAMPLE: Do fairies really exist?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 真的有神仙吗？
Sense.EXAMPLE: Tom acts as if I don’t exist at times.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 汤姆有时表现得就像我不存在一样。

Sense.DEF: to stay alive, especially in a difficult situation when you do not have enough money, food etc
Sense.TRAN: 维持生存〔尤指勉强糊口〕

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The hostages existed on bread and water.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 人质靠面包和水生存。

Sense.DEF: the state of existing

GramExa.EXAMPLE: It is impossible to prove the existence of God.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 无法证明上帝的存在。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The organization has been in existence for 25 years.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 该组织已存在25年了。

Sense.EXAMPLE: Scientists have many theories about how the universe first came into existence started to exist.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 关于宇宙的起源﹐科学家有多种理论。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The very existence of the museum is threatened by lack of funding.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 博物馆的生存受到资金缺乏的威胁。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: the continued existence of economic inequalities
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 经济不平等的持续存在

Sense.DEF: the type of life that someone has, especially when it is bad or unhappy
Sense.EXAMPLE: Pablo led a miserable existence when he first moved to San Juan.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 巴勃罗刚搬到圣胡安时﹐生活很悲惨。

Sense.DEF: existing now
Sense.EXAMPLE: existent differences
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 现存的差别

Sense.DEF: something that is real and exists
relating to the existence of humans or to existentialism
Sense.TRAN: 关于人类存在的﹔存在主义的

Sense.DEF: the belief in philosophy that people are responsible for their own actions and experiences, and that the world has no meaning
present or being used now
Sense.EXAMPLE: the existing laws
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 现行法律
Sense.EXAMPLE: The service is available to all existing customers.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这项服务现有的客户均可享受。

Sense.DEF: a door or space through which you can leave a public room, building etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: We made for the nearest exit.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们走向最近的出口。
Sense.EXAMPLE: an exit door
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 出口门
Sense.EXAMPLE: Two men were blocking her exit.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 两个男人挡住了她出去的路。

GramExa.GLOSS: a special door used only when there is a fire etc
GramExa.COLLOTRAN: 太平门﹔紧急出口﹔消防门

Sense.DEF: when you leave a room or building
Sense.EXAMPLE: They made a quick exit when they saw the police approaching.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们看见警察来了便迅速离去。

Sense.DEF: a place where vehicles can leave a road such as a mo-torway, and join another road
Sense.EXAMPLE: Take the next exit for Lynchburg.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 从下一个出口驶出到林奇堡。

Sense.DEF: when someone stops being involved in a competition or business, especially because they have not been successful
Sense.TRAN: 退出〔尤指因未成功而停止参与竞争或事务〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: France’s early exit from the World Cup
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 法国队在世界杯上的早早出局

Sense.DEF: to leave a place

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I exited through a side window.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我从侧面的一扇窗户钻了出去。

Sense.EXAMPLE: He exited the courtroom in a fury.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他怒气冲冲地离开了审判室。

Sense.DEF: to stop using a computer program
Sense.EXAMPLE: Press F3 to exit.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 按F3键退出。

Sense.DEF: used in the instructions of a play to tell an actor to leave the stage
Sense.TRAN: 〔剧本里的舞台指示﹐一个演员〕退场﹐下场
Sense.EXAMPLE: Exit Hamlet, bearing the body of Polonius.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 哈姆雷特扛着波洛尼厄斯的尸体退场。

Sense.DEF: the activity of asking people how they have voted in an election in order to discover the likely result
a plan for ending your involvementtaking part in an activity, such as a war or a business, in a way that causes no damage or problems
Sense.TRAN: 〔为避免造成损失或麻烦而从战争﹑商务活动等中脱身的〕退出策略
Sense.EXAMPLE: The President convinced people that he had a workable exit strategy to free his forces from the conflict.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 总统让人们相信他有切实可行的策略抽身而退﹐从这一冲突中撤军。

Sense.DEF: a situation in which a lot of people leave a particular place at the same time

GramExa.EXAMPLE: A massive exodus of doctors is forcing the government to recruit from abroad.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 大批医生的离去正迫使政府从国外招聘。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: the exodus from the countryside to the towns in the 19th century
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 19世纪大批人离开乡村来到城镇

Sense.EXAMPLE: I joined the mass exodus for drinks during the interval.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 幕间休息时我随着人流出去喝东西。

Sense.DEF: an ex-officio member of an organization is only a member because of their rank or position
Sense.TRAN: 〔组织成员〕当然的 〔指其级别或职位使其成为组织的一员〕

Sense.DEF: to state officially that someone who has been blamed for something is not guilty

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He was totally exonerated of any blame.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他被完全免责。

Sense.DEF: an exorbitant price, amount of money etc is much higher than it should be

GramExa.EXAMPLE: exorbitant rates of interest
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 过高的利率

Sense.DEF: a process during which someone tries to make an evil spirit leave a place by saying special words, or a ceremony when this is done
the process of making yourself forget a bad memory or experience
Sense.TRAN: 〔对不愉快的记忆或经历的〕设法忘却﹐淡忘

Sense.DEF: someone who tries to make evil spirits leave a place
to force evil spirits to leave a place by using special words and ceremonies
Sense.TRAN: 〔通过念咒语或驱邪仪式〕驱除〔邪魔〕

Sense.DEF: to make yourself forget a bad memory or experience
Sense.TRAN: 设法忘却〔不愉快的记忆或经历〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: trying to exorcise the past
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 努力忘掉过去

Sense.DEF: the hard parts on the outside of the body of creatures such as insects and crabs
something that is exotic seems unusual and interesting because it is related to a foreign country – use this to show approval
Sense.TRAN: 异国风情的﹐外国情调的〔含褒义〕
Sense.EXAMPLE: exotic birds
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 外国的奇异鸟类
Sense.EXAMPLE: exotic places
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 有异国风情的地方

Sense.DEF: things that are unusual and exciting, especially because they come from foreign countries
a dancer who takes off her clothes while dancing
to become larger in size, number, or amount, or to make something become larger
Sense.EXAMPLE: Water expands as it freezes.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 水结冰时会膨胀。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Sydney’s population expanded rapidly in the 1960s.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 20世纪60年代﹐悉尼的人口迅速增加。
Sense.EXAMPLE: exercises that expand the chest muscles
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 扩展胸肌的运动
Sense.EXAMPLE: his expanding waistline
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他那逐渐增大的腰围

Sense.DEF: if a company, business etc expands, or if someone expands it, they open new shops, factories etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: The computer industry has expanded greatly over the last decade.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 计算机行业在过去十年间大大地发展起来。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The hotel wants to expand its business by adding a swimming pool.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 该酒店想添个游泳池来扩展业务。
Sense.EXAMPLE: the rapidly expanding field of information technology
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 迅速发展的信息技术领域

GramExa.EXAMPLE: We have plans to expand into the U.S. market.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们有计划把业务扩展到美国市场。

Sense.DEF: to become more confident and start to talk more
Sense.EXAMPLE: After a few whiskies he started to expand a little.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 几杯威士忌下肚﹐他打开了话匣子。

Sense.DEF: to add more details or information to something that you have already said
Sense.EXAMPLE: Payne later expanded on his initial statement.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 佩恩后来对他最初的声明作了进一步说明。

Sense.DEF: able to be increased or made larger
Sense.EXAMPLE: a computer with 2GB RAM expandable to 4GB RAM
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 内存2G﹑可扩展至4G的计算机

Sense.DEF: a very large area of water, sky, land etc

GramExa.EXAMPLE: an expanse of blue sky
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 广阔的蓝天

GramExa.EXAMPLE: the vast expanse of the ocean
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 一望无际的海洋

Sense.DEF: when something increases in size, range, amount etc
Sense.TRAN: 〔尺寸﹑范围﹑数量等的〕扩大﹔增加

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The rapid expansion of cities can cause social and economic problems.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 城市规模的迅速扩大会带来各种社会和经济问题。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: an expansion in student numbers
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 学生人数的增加

Sense.DEF: when a company, business etc becomes larger by opening new shops, factories etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: The industry underwent a period of rapid expansion.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 该产业经历了一轮快速扩张。

Sense.DEF: an idea, story etc that is based on one that is simpler or more general
Sense.EXAMPLE: The novel is an expansion of a short story he wrote about forty years ago.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这部小说由他大约40年前写的一篇短篇小说扩展而成。

Sense.DEF: encouraging a business or economy to become bigger and more successful
Sense.TRAN: 促进企业[经济]扩张的﹐扩张性的
Sense.EXAMPLE: expansionary fiscal policy
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 扩张性财政政策

Sense.DEF: a circuit board that fits into a computer and makes it possible for the computer to do more things, for example play sounds or video pictures, or use a telephone line
when a country or group increases the amount of land or power that they have – used especially to show disapproval
Sense.EXAMPLE: military expansionism
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 军事扩张主义

Sense.DEF: a place on a computer system circuit board that can hold an expansion card
very friendly and willing to talk a lot
Sense.EXAMPLE: Hauser was in an expansive mood.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 豪泽心情豁朗。

Sense.DEF: very large in area, or using a lot of space
Sense.EXAMPLE: expansive beaches
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 广阔的海滩
Sense.EXAMPLE: She flung her arms out in an expansive gesture.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她尽情地张开双臂。

Sense.DEF: including a lot of information and using a lot of words
Sense.EXAMPLE: an expansive definition
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 宽泛的定义
Sense.EXAMPLE: It was written in an expansive style.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这是用洋洋洒洒的风格写成的。

Sense.DEF: relating to business or economy becoming bigger or more successful
Sense.TRAN: 促进企业[经济]发展的﹐扩张性的
Sense.EXAMPLE: expansive economic policies
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 扩张性经济政策

Sense.DEF: an expatriate
to speak or write in detail about a particular subject
someone who lives in a foreign country
Sense.EXAMPLE: British expatriates living in Spain
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 生活在西班牙的英国侨民

Sense.DEF: to think that something will happen because it seems likely or has been planned

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I expect to be back within a week.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我预计一周之内回来。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: The company expects to complete work in April.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 公司预期在4月完工。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Emergency repairs were expected to take three weeks.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 抢修工作预计要花三个星期。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: I didn’t expect him to stay so long.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我没有料到他会待那么久。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: There’s the doorbell — I expect it’ll be my mother.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 有人按门铃﹐估计是我母亲。

Sense.EXAMPLE: He will be hard to beat. I fully expect am completely sure about that and I’m ready.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他很难击败。我确信这一点﹐不过我准备好了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘Who are you?’ he murmured, only half expecting thinking it was possible, but not likely her to answer.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “你是谁？”他低声问道﹐预计她可能不会回答。
Sense.EXAMPLE: He didn’t get his expected pay rise.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他没有得到他预想的加薪。

GramExa.GLOSS: in the way that was planned or thought likely to happen
GramExa.EXAMPLE: As expected, the whole family was shocked by the news.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 不出所料﹐全家人对这个消息都感到震惊。

GramExa.GLOSS: used to say that you are not surprised by something, especially something unpleasant
GramExa.COLLOTRAN: 某事在预料之中﹐某事并不意外〔尤指令人不愉快的事〕
GramExa.EXAMPLE: A little nervousness is only to be expected when you are starting a new job.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 开始一项新工作时有点紧张是不足为奇的。

Sense.DEF: to demand that someone does something because it is a duty or seems reasonable

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The officer expects complete obedience from his troops.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这位军官要求部下绝对服从。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I can’t expect her to be on time if I’m late myself.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我要是自己都迟到就无法要求她准时。

GramExa.PROPFORM: expect a lot of sb/expect too much of sb
GramExa.GLOSS: think someone can do more than may be possible
GramExa.EXAMPLE: The school expects a lot of its students.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这所学校对学生要求很高。

Sense.SIGNTRAN: 认为某人会到达/某事会发生
Sense.DEF: to believe that someone or something is going to arrive
Sense.EXAMPLE: We’re expecting Alison home any minute now.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们想艾利森现在随时会到家。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Snow is expected by the weekend.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 预计周末会下雪。
Sense.EXAMPLE: an expected crowd of 80,000 people
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 预计会来80,000人

Sense.DEF: to think that you will find that someone or something has a particular quality or does a particular thing
Sense.EXAMPLE: I expected her to be taller than me, not shorter.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我曾以为她个子比我高﹐不会比我矮。

Sense.DEF: if a woman is expecting, she is going to have a baby
used to say that you are not surprised by something unpleasant or disappoint-ing
Sense.TRAN: 这有什么奇怪？ 你还能指望什么？
Sense.EXAMPLE: He was late, but what do you expect?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他迟到了﹐可这有什么奇怪呢？

Sense.DEF: used to say that it is unreasonable to think that something will happen or be true
Sense.EXAMPLE: If I can’t help her, how can you expect to?
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 如果我都帮不了她﹐你又能指望怎么样呢？

Sense.DEF: used to introduce or agree with a statement that you think is probably true
Sense.EXAMPLE: I expect you’re right.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我觉得你说得对。
Sense.EXAMPLE: ‘Do you think they’re going to attack?’ ‘I expect so.’
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: “你觉得他们会进攻吗？”“我看会。”

Tail.TailContent: This graph shows how common the different grammar patterns of the verb expect are. 本图表所示为动词expect构成的不同语法模式的使用频率。

Sense.DEF: the feeling that something pleasant or exciting is going to happen
Sense.EXAMPLE: I saw the look of expectancy in the children’s eyes.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我从孩子们的眼神中看到了期盼。

Sense.DEF: hopeful that something good or exciting will happen, or showing this
Sense.EXAMPLE: a row of expectant faces
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一张张满怀期待的面孔

Sense.DEF: a mother or father whose baby will be born soon

Tail.EXAMPLE: He looked expectantly at Sarah, but she didn’t speak.
Tail.EXAMPLETRAN: 他期待地看着萨拉﹐但她没有说话。

Sense.DEF: what you think or hope will happen

GramExa.EXAMPLE: For some time he lived with the expectation that he was going to die.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 有一段时间﹐他预料自己快要不行了。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Anne left Germany in the expectation of seeing her family again before very long.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 安妮离开了德国﹐期待着很快就能与家人重逢。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Against all expectations, getting up at five is actually easier in winter.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 完全没想到﹐冬天5点钟起床其实挺容易做到。

Sense.EXAMPLE: Having raised expectations made people more hopeful, he went on to help only a few people.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他唤起了大家的希望﹐但接着只是帮助了几个人。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Profits are below expectations.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 利润低于预期。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Gina has succeeded beyond our expectations.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 吉娜取得的成功超出了我们的预期。

Sense.EXAMPLE: The show exceeded all expectations was much better than expected.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这场演出比人们预期的要好得多。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: His performance did not live up to our expectations was not as good as we expected.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他的表现有负众望。

Sense.EXAMPLE: The number of people who attended fell short of expectations was lower than expected.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 出席的人数比预期的要少。

Sense.DEF: a feeling or belief about the way something should be or how someone should behave

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Women who have high expectations of marriage are often disappointed.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 对婚姻怀有很高期望的女性常常会感到失望。

Sense.EXAMPLE: Some people have totally unrealistic expectations of both medical and nursing staff.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 有些人对医护人员的期望完全不切实际。

Sense.DEF: the number of years that someone is likely to live
a type of medicine that you take to help you cough up phlegma sticky substance from your lungs
to force liquid out of your mouth
action that is quickest or most effective in a particular situation, even if it is morally wrong
Sense.TRAN: 不得已而做的事﹔有效(但不道德的)行动﹔权宜之计
Sense.EXAMPLE: the ethics of political expediency
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 政治上权宜之举的伦理问题

Sense.DEF: helping you to deal with a problem quickly and effectively although sometimes in a way that is not morally right
Sense.TRAN: 便捷有效(但不道德)的﹔权宜的
Sense.EXAMPLE: This solution is politically expedient but may well cause long-term problems.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这种解决方法是政治上的权宜之计﹐但会引起长远的问题。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: We think it is expedient to make a good-will gesture to the new administration.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们认为向新一任政府示好是权宜之计。

Sense.DEF: a quick and effective way of dealing with a problem
Sense.EXAMPLE: Moore escaped by the simple expedient of lying down in a clump of grass.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 穆尔急中生智﹐躺倒在草丛中得以脱身。

Sense.DEF: to make a process or action happen more quickly
Sense.EXAMPLE: strategies to expedite the decision-making process
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 加快决策进程的策略

Sense.DEF: a long and carefully organized journey, especially to a dangerous or unfamiliar place, or the people that make this journey
Sense.TRAN: 远征﹔探险﹔远征队﹔探险队
Sense.EXAMPLE: an expedition to the North Pole
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 北极探险
Sense.EXAMPLE: another Qomolangma expedition
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 又一次珠穆朗玛峰探险

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He went on an expedition to Borneo.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他去婆罗洲探险了。

Sense.DEF: a short journey, usually made for a particular purpose
Sense.TRAN: 〔一般指有特定目的的〕短途出行
Sense.EXAMPLE: a shopping expedition
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 购物之行
Sense.EXAMPLE: a fishing expedition
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 钓鱼之行

Sense.DEF: a group of soldiers that is sent to another country to fight in a war
in a quick and effective way
Sense.EXAMPLE: All issues presented to the court are considered as fairly and expeditiously as possible.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 向法庭提交的所有问题都得到了尽可能公正和迅速有效的审议。

RunOn.EXAMPLE: an expeditious system for examining claims for refugee status
RunOn.EXAMPLETRAN: 迅速高效地处理难民身份申请的审查制度

Sense.DEF: to officially force someone to leave a school or organization

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Two girls were expelled from school for taking drugs.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 两名女生因吸毒而被学校开除。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: The main opposition leader was expelled from her party.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 主要反对党的领导人被开除出其政党。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: He was expelled for making racist remarks.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他因发表种族主义言论而被开除。

Sense.DEF: to force a foreigner to leave a country, especially because they have broken the law or for political reasons
Sense.TRAN: 〔尤指因犯法或政治原因而〕驱逐〔外国人〕

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Foreign priests were expelled from the country.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 外国牧师被驱逐出境。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Three diplomats were expelled for spying.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 三名外交官因从事间谍活动而被驱逐出境。

Sense.DEF: to force air, water, or gas etc out of your body or out of a container
to use or spend a lot of energy etc in order to do something

GramExa.EXAMPLE: People of different ages expend different amounts of energy.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 不同年龄的人消耗的能量有所不同。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Manufacturers have expended a lot of time and effort trying to improve computer security.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 制造商花费了大量的时间和精力试图提高计算机的安全性。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: A great deal of time and money has been expended on creating a pleasant office atmosphere.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 为创造舒心的办公环境已花费了大量的时间和金钱。

Sense.DEF: not needed enough to be kept or saved
Sense.EXAMPLE: It’s a sad moment when a man loses his job and discovers that he is expendable.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 一个人丢掉工作并发现自己无足轻重的那一刻会很难过。

Sense.DEF: the total amount of money that a government, organization, or person spends during a particular period of time

GramExa.EXAMPLE: expenditure on research and development
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 研发开支

Sense.EXAMPLE: huge cuts in public expenditure the amount of money a government spends on services for the public
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 大幅度削减公共开支
Sense.EXAMPLE: government expenditure on education
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 政府的教育开支

EXAMPLE.GLOSS: spending by a company on buildings, machinery, equipment etc

Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 〔公司的〕资本开支

GramExa.EXAMPLE: an expenditure of £1 million
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 100万英镑的支出额

Sense.DEF: the action of spending or using time, money, energy etc
Sense.TRAN: 〔时间﹑金钱﹑精力等的〕耗费﹐花费
Sense.EXAMPLE: the expenditure of time and money on your house or garden
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 你在房子或花园上所花费的时间和金钱

Sense.DEF: the amount of money that you spend on something
Sense.EXAMPLE: He borrowed £150,000 and used the money for legal expenses.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 他借了15万英镑用于支付律师费。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Conference rooms were equipped at great expense.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 装备会议室花费巨大。

Sense.DEF: money that you spend on things such as travel and food while you are doing your job, and which your employer then pays to you

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Can you claim this meal on expenses?
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这顿饭你能报销吗？

Sense.DEF: if something is done at the expense of someone or something else, it is only achieved by doing something that could harm the other person or thing
Sense.TRAN: 以损害某人/某事物为代价
Sense.EXAMPLE: the growth in short breaks, at the expense of longer package holidays
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 短假增多﹐以牺牲时间较长的包价旅游为代价

Subsense.DEF: if you do something at someone’s expense, they pay for you to do it
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Her mansion was refurnished at taxpayers’ expense.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她的宅第由纳税人出钱重新布置了一番。

Subsense.DEF: if you make jokes at someone’s expense, you laugh about them and make them seem stupid or silly
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Louis kept making jokes at his wife’s expense.
Subsense.EXAMPLETRAN: 路易斯不断地嘲笑妻子。

Sense.DEF: having all of your costs for hotels, travel, meals etc paid for by someone else
Sense.TRAN: 〔酒店﹑旅行﹑用餐等〕所有费用均由他人支付的
Sense.EXAMPLE: The prize is an all-expenses-paid trip to Rio.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 奖品是去里约热内卢的全程免费旅游。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: Is it worth the extra expense to get a room with a sea view?
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 值不值得为海景房多付钱啊？

Collocate.EXAMPLE: Paying extra for leather seats seemed like an unnecessary expense.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 另加钱坐皮座椅似乎是不必要的花费。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: money that you spend on rent, food, and things such as electricity, gas etc
Collocate.EXAMPLE: She receives £80 a week, from which she must pay for all her living expenses.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 她每周收入80英镑﹐得用这笔钱支付所有的生活费。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: money that a company spends on running its business
Collocate.EXAMPLE: We must reduce our operating expenses.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们必须减少营运开支。

Collocate.EXAMPLE: We had to get a loan to pay for my husband’s medical expenses.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 我们只得贷款支付我丈夫的医疗费。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: money spent looking after a house and the people in it
the cost of arranging a funeral
used when saying that something costs a lot of money
Collocate.EXAMPLE: The tiles were imported at great expense from Italy.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 这些瓷砖是高价从意大利进口的。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: used when saying that you pay for something yourself
Collocate.EXAMPLE: He had copies of the book printed at his own expense.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 他自己花钱印了这本书。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: paid for by the public through taxes
Collocate.EXAMPLE: The bridge was built at public expense.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 这座桥是公费修建的。

Collocate.COLLOC: go to the expense of doing sth
Collocate.COLLGLOSS: do something that costs a lot of money
Collocate.EXAMPLE: The council must now decide whether to go to the expense of appealing through the courts.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 地方议会现在必须决定是否要出钱向法院上诉。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: spend a lot of money to buy the best things
Collocate.EXAMPLE: Her parents spared no expense in arranging the wedding.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 她父母不惜花费﹐大办婚礼。

Collocate.COLLGLOSS: have to pay for something
Collocate.EXAMPLE: Potential buyers incur the expense of a survey and legal fees.
Collocate.EXAMPLETRAN: 潜在买家要承担房屋鉴定费及法律费用。

Sense.DEF: money that is available to someone who works for a company so that they can pay for meals, hotels etc when travelling or entertaining people for work
Sense.TRAN: 〔由公司支付食宿费等的〕费用账户
Sense.EXAMPLE: I have an expense account and spend about £10,000 a year on entertaining.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我有一个费用账户﹐一年大约花一万英镑招待客户。

Sense.DEF: costing a lot of money
Sense.EXAMPLE: the most expensive restaurant in town
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 城里最贵的餐馆
Sense.EXAMPLE: Petrol is becoming more and more expensive.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 汽油越来越贵了。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Photography is an expensive hobby.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 摄影是一项很花钱的业余爱好。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The house was too big and expensive to run.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 房子太大﹐养起来很费钱。

Sense.EXAMPLE: For low-income families, children’s safety equipment can be prohibitively expensive so expensive that most people cannot afford it.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 对于低收入家庭来说﹐儿童的安全设备贵得让人望而却步。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Employing the wrong builder can be a horribly expensive mistake.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 用错建筑工人有时会是代价高昂的错误。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Her husband had expensive tastes liked expensive things.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她丈夫喜欢的东西都很贵。

Exponent.DEF: costing a lot of money
Exponent.EXAMPLE: an expensive car
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 昂贵的汽车
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Apartments in the city are very expensive.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 该城市的公寓房非常贵。

Exponent.DEF: costing a lot of money. You use high about rents/fees/prices/costs. Don’t use expensive with these words.
Exponent.TRAN: 价格高的〔rents/fees/prices/costs要和high 连用﹐不能和expensive 连用〕
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Rents are very high in this area.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 这一地区房租很高。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Lawyers charge high fees.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 律师收费很高。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: the high cost of living in Japan
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 日本高昂的生活费用

Exponent.DEF: expensive compared to the usual price
Exponent.EXAMPLE: £3.50 seems rather dear for a cup of coffee.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 一杯咖啡要3.5英镑﹐似乎相当贵。

Exponent.DEF: expensive
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The clothes are beautiful but pricey.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 这些衣服很美﹐不过太贵了。

Exponent.DEF: expensive in a way that wastes money
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Upgrading the system would be very costly.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 给系统升级太费钱了。
Exponent.EXAMPLE: They were anxious to avoid a costly legal battle.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 他们急于避免一场耗费巨大的诉讼战。

Exponent.DEF: to be very expensive
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The necklace must have cost a fortune!
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 这条项链肯定花了一大笔钱！

Exponent.DEF: much too expensive
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Some accountants charge exorbitant fees.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 有些会计师收费过高。

Exponent.DEF: astronomical prices, costs, and fees are extremely high
Exponent.EXAMPLE: the astronomical cost of developing a new spacecraft
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 开发新型航天器的巨额费用

Exponent.DEF: too expensive and not worth the price
Exponent.EXAMPLE: The DVDs were vastly overpriced.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 这些数字影碟定价过高。

Exponent.DEF: someone does not have enough money to buy or do something
Exponent.EXAMPLE: Most people can’t afford to send their children to private schools.
Exponent.EXAMPLETRAN: 大多数人没钱送子女上私立学校。

Sense.DEF: knowledge or skill that you gain from doing a job or activity, or the process of doing this

GramExa.EXAMPLE: You’ve got a lot of experience of lecturing.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 你有很多讲课的经验。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: my experience in many areas of the music business
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我在音乐行业许多领域所积累的经验
GramExa.EXAMPLE: He had no previous experience of managing a farm.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 他以前没有经营农场的经验。

Sense.EXAMPLE: The advice in the booklet reflects the practical experience we have gained experience gained by actually doing something, rather than knowledge from books etc.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 小册子中的建议反映了我们所获得的实践经验。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I had some experience in fashion design.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我有一些时装设计方面的经验。
Sense.EXAMPLE: She was turned down on the grounds of lack of experience.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她因缺乏经验而被拒绝。
Sense.EXAMPLE: I have first-hand experience experience gained by doing something myself of running a school.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 我有办学的亲身经验。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The programme enables pupils to gain some experience of the world of work.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这项活动能使小学生获得一些工作经验。

Sense.DEF: knowledge that you gain about life and the world by being in different situations and meeting different people, or the process of gaining this

GramExa.EXAMPLE: In his experience, women did not like getting their feet wet and muddy.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 据他的经验来看﹐妇女不喜欢脚上沾到水或泥。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Being a parent isn’t easy, as I know from experience.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 经验告诉我﹐当父母不容易。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: All animals appear to have some capacity to learn from experience.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 所有动物似乎都有某种从经验中学习的能力。
GramExa.EXAMPLE: I speak from bitter experience having learnt something because something unpleasant happened.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 我说这话是因为自己有过惨痛的教训。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: From personal experience, she knew and understood the problems of alcohol addiction.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 她有切身体会﹐知道并理解酒瘾所带来的种种问题。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Beth’s experience suggests that people don’t really change deep down.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 贝丝的经历表明人的本性并不会真正改变。

Sense.DEF: something that happens to you or something you do, especially when this has an effect on what you feel or think
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 儿时的经历

GramExa.EXAMPLE: This was my first experience of living with other people.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这是我第一次与人同住。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Failing an exam was a new experience for me.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 考试不及格对我来说还是第一次。

Sense.EXAMPLE: I had a similar experience last year.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 去年我经历了类似的事情。
Sense.EXAMPLE: The two children in this story have been through a lot of bad experiences.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 这个故事中的两个孩子遭遇了许多不愉快的事情。
Sense.EXAMPLE: Parachuting is quite an experience.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 跳伞真可谓是不同寻常的经历。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: This romantic evening cruise is a memorable experience.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这趟浪漫的乘船夜游是一次令人难忘的经历。

GramExa.GLOSS: a situation in which you feel, hear, or see something that affects you strongly and makes you believe in God
GramExa.COLLOTRAN: 宗教体验〔使人信仰上帝的体验〕
GramExa.EXAMPLE: This kind of religious experience was a sign of God’s special favour.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 这种宗教体验是上帝特别恩惠的表示。

Sense.DEF: events or knowledge shared by the members of a particular society or group of people
Sense.TRAN: 黑人/女性/俄罗斯人等的经验[体验]
Sense.EXAMPLE: No writer expresses the black experience with such passion as Toni Morisson.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 没有哪位作家像托尼·莫里森那样以如此充满激情的笔调来描述黑人的体验。

Sense.DEF: a system in which a student can work for a company in order to learn about a job, or the period during which a student does this
Sense.EXAMPLE: Ella is about to do work experience with a clothing manufacturer.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 埃拉将去一家制衣厂实习。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: students on work experience
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 在实习的学生

Sense.DEF: if you experience a problem, event, or situation, it happens to you or affects you

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Many old people will experience problems as the result of retirement.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 许多老人会由于退休而遇到各种问题。

Sense.EXAMPLE: Children need to experience things for themselves in order to learn from them.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 儿童需要亲身经历事情以便从中学习。

Sense.DEF: to feel a particular emotion, pain etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: Many women experience feelings of nausea during pregnancy.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 许多女性在怀孕期间会有恶心想吐的感觉。

Sense.DEF: possessing skills or knowledge because you have done something often or for a long time
Sense.EXAMPLE: an experienced pilot
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 经验丰富的飞行员
Sense.EXAMPLE: an experienced public speaker
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 老练的公开演讲者
Sense.EXAMPLE: She is experienced and self-assured.
Sense.EXAMPLETRAN: 她经验丰富且充满自信。

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Blake’s very experienced in microsurgery.
GramExa.EXAMPLETRAN: 布莱克在显微外科手术方面极富经验。

Sense.DEF: based on experience or related to experience
Sense.TRAN: 由经验得来的﹔与经验相关的
Sense.EXAMPLE: experiential approaches to learning
